abstract.p: Correction of May 7 article on rivalry between Moscow and St Petersburg; historical facts noted

block.p: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about renewed rivalry between Moscow and St. Petersburg misstated the history of St. Petersburg's name and referred incompletely to the shift of the Russian capital from St. Petersburg to Moscow. St. Petersburg was renamed Petrograd as a patriotic gesture after war broke out with Germany in 1914; it was not renamed by Lenin. In 1918, Moscow was made the capital in part because it was easier to defend than St. Petersburg, not solely as a symbolic stamp of the triumph of Communism over the czar.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about renewed rivalry between Moscow and St. Petersburg misstated the history of St. Petersburg's name and referred incompletely to the shift of the Russian capital from St. Petersburg to Moscow. St. Petersburg was renamed Petrograd as a patriotic gesture after war broke out with Germany in 1914; it was not renamed by Lenin. In 1918, Moscow was made the capital in part because it was easier to defend than St. Petersburg, not solely as a symbolic stamp of the triumph of Communism over the czar.
